title: Feminism in Thomas Hardy's a laodicean
abstract: This thesis deals mainly with the thesis writer's hypothesis that Thomas Hardy's central female character in A Laodicean reflects the characteristics of a feminist. By using some criticism on A Laodicean and by doing characterization of Paula Power, the thesis writer will show that she is a feminist. The characteristics that prove that Paula Power is a feminist, Are the following: Paula is a modern type of woman, firm, educated and outspoken, very independent, and highly principled. The thesis writer then concludes that Paula Power shows her being a feminist in every area of her life: in religion, education, marriage, principle, tradition, and possession.
contributors: Guillermina L. Verzosa (Advisor 1); ANITA LIE (Examination Committee 1)
source: Undergraduate Thesis No. 502/SING/1997; Maria Irawati Yulianto (11489054)
subjects: HARDY, THOMAS, 1840-1928-CHARACTERS-WOMEN; HARDY, THOMAS,1840-1928-CRITICISM AND INTERPRETATIONS
